ErrorsCodes.400: The server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error.
ErrorsCodes.401: The client must authenticate itself to get the requested response.
ErrorsCodes.403: The client does not have access rights to the content; that is, it is unauthorized, so the server is refusing to give the requested resource.
ErrorsCodes.404: The server cannot find the requested resource.
ErrorsCodes.405: The request method is known by the server but is not supported by the target resource.
ErrorsCodes.408: This response is sent on an idle connection by some servers, even without any previous request by the client.
ErrorsCodes.410: This response is sent when the requested content has been permanently deleted from server, with no forwarding address.
ErrorsCodes.413: Request entity is larger than limits defined by server.
ErrorsCodes.414: The URI requested by the client is longer than the server is willing to interpret.
ErrorsCodes.415: The media format of the requested data is not supported by the server, so the server is rejecting the request.
ErrorsCodes.429: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time.
ErrorsCodes.431: The server is unwilling to process the request because its header fields are too large.
ErrorsCodes.500: The server has encountered a situation it does not know how to handle.
ErrorsCodes.502: The server, while working as a gateway to get a response needed to handle the request, got an invalid response.
ErrorsCodes.503: The server is not ready to handle the request.
ErrorsCodes.504: This error response is given when the server is acting as a gateway and cannot get a response in time.
